data.Symptoms: Wilting and yellowing
data.Causes: Caused by Ralstonia solanacearum.
data.Treatment:
Use resistant tomato varieties.
 Avoid planting near tobacco.

data.Symptoms: Mosaic-like patterns on leaves.
data.Causes: Caused by Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV).
data.Treatment:
Use resistant tomato varieties.
 Avoid planting near tobacco.

data.Symptoms: Water-soaked blossoms shrivel.
data.Causes: Caused by Erwinia amylovora.
data.Treatment:
Prune affected branches.
Apply copper-based sprays during dormant season.

data.Symptoms: Wrinkled stems and brown-to-black roots.
data.Causes: : Caused by Agrobacterium tumefaciens.
data.Treatment:
Prune affected branches.
Apply copper-based sprays during dormant season.

data.Symptoms: Yellowish-green spots on leaves.
data.Causes: Caused by Xanthomonas campestris.
data.Treatment:
Use disease-resistant bean varieties.
Avoid overhead irrigation.

data.Symptoms: Soft decay in fleshy tissue fruits.
data.Causes: Various bacteria.
data.Treatment:
Use disease-resistant bean varieties.
Avoid overhead irrigation.

data.Symptoms: Stunted growth, yellowing, and wilting of above-ground parts.
data.Causes: Caused by Pseudomonas solanacearum.
data.Treatment:
Remove and destroy infected plants.
Rotate crops to prevent recurrence.

data.Symptoms: Yellowish-green spots on leaves.
data.Causes: Caused by Pseudomonas syringae.
data.Treatment:
Remove and destroy infected plants.
Rotate crops to prevent recurrence.

data.Symptoms: Water-soaked blossoms shrivel.
data.Causes: Caused by Erwinia amylovora.
data.Treatment:
Prune affected branches.
Apply copper-based sprays during dormant season.

data.Symptoms: Black spots on leaves.
data.Causes: Caused by Diplocarpon rosae.
data.Treatment:
Prune affected branches.
Apply copper-based sprays during dormant season.

data.Symptoms: Stunted growth, Leaf yellowing.
data.Causes: Caused By Helicobasidium mompa, a fungal pathogen.
data.Treatment:
Crop rotation.
Fungicidal treatments.
Use resistant varieties.

data.Symptoms: Decreased tuber yield and quality.
data.Causes: Caused By Verticillium dahliae, a soil-borne fungus.
data.Treatment:
Use disease-resistant bean varieties.
Avoid overhead irrigation.

data.Symptoms: Brown spots on leaves, Yellowing and leaf drop.
data.Causes: caused by Fungal disease (Alternaria solani).
data.Treatment:
Remove infected leaves.
Apply fungicides.
Remove and destroy infected plant parts.

data.Symptoms: Sunken lesions on the leaves and fruit, Lesions can eventually become black and rot.
data.Causes: Fungal disease (Colletotrichum spp.).
data.Treatment:
Remove infected leaves.
Apply fungicides.
Remove and destroy infected plant parts.

data.Symptoms: Yellow spots with rings resembling a target or bullâ€™s-eye, Tissue death leading to holes in the foliage.
data.Causes: Fungi (Alternaria brassicicola and A. brassicae).
data.Treatment:
Good cultural practices (drip irrigation, sanitation, crop rotation).
Biopesticides like Bacillus amyloliquefaciens and Bacillus subtilis.

data.Symptoms: Dark flecks on the leaves that spread into lesions, Angular lesions that make the leaves look ragged.
data.Causes: Two different species of bacteria: Pseudomonas syringae pv. maculicola and Xanthomonas campestris pv. armoraciae.
data.Treatment:
Good cultural practices (drip irrigation, sanitation, crop rotation).
Biopesticides like Bacillus amyloliquefaciens and Bacillus subtilis.

data.Symptoms: Yellow patches on the upper side of leaves, White, fuzzy growth on the undersides of leaves, Leaves may curl or become distorted.
data.Causes: Fungal disease (Peronospora parasitica).
data.Treatment:
Remove and destroy infected leaves.
Apply fungicides containing copper or mancozeb.
Practice crop rotation.

data.Symptoms: Yellow V-shaped lesions at the leaf margins, Lesions expand and turn brown or black, Wilting and death of affected leaves.
data.Causes: Bacterial disease (Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris).
data.Treatment:
Remove and destroy infected leaves.
Apply fungicides containing copper or mancozeb.
Practice crop rotation.

data.Symptoms: White powdery patches on leaves, stems, and sometimes fruits.
data.Causes: Fungal infection, favored by warm, dry conditions with high humidity
data.Treatment: Remove affected leaves, apply fungicides containing sulfur or potassium bicarbonate, improve air circulation, and avoid overhead watering.

data.Symptoms: Leaves may become yellow and wilted, leading to reduced photosynthesis and yield.
data.Causes: wilting and yellowing of leaves, Rust can appear as orange or reddish spots on leaves.
data.Treatment: Remove affected leaves, apply fungicides containing sulfur or potassium bicarbonate, improve air circulation, and avoid overhead watering.

data.Symptoms: Raised lesions on leaves, fruit, and stems, yellowing, premature fruit drop
data.Causes: Bacterial infection
data.Treatment: Prune infected parts, copper-based sprays

data.Symptoms: Leaf spots can cause leaf distortion and premature leaf drop
data.Causes: It enters the tree through the roots, leading to decay in both the roots and lower trunk
data.Treatment:
Practice good sanitation by removing fallen leaves and fruit.
Avoid overhead watering, as moisture promotes disease spread

data.Symptoms: White powdery spots on leaves, stunted growth, leaf curling
data.Causes: Fungal infection
data.Treatment: Prune affected leaves, fungicide, increase air circulation

data.Symptoms:
Sudden wilting of vines, especially during hot weather.
Yellowing and browning of lower leaves
data.Causes: Bacterial infection, it blocks water transport, leading to wilting
data.Treatment: prevention by controlling cucumber beetles using insecticides

data.Symptoms:
Dark, sunken lesions on fruit, often with pinkish spore masses.
Lesions may expand rapidly, leading to fruit decay and loss
data.Causes: Fungal infection spread through splashing water and infected plant debris
data.Treatment: Remove and destroy infected fruits, apply fungicides containing copper or thiophanate-methyl, practice good sanitation

data.Symptoms: Grayish-brown fuzzy growth on ripe fruit
data.Causes: High humidity and dampness, Poor air circulation
data.Treatment: Remove infected fruit promptly, Improve airflow around plants

data.Symptoms: Reddish or purplish distorted leaves in spring, leading to leaf curling, thickening, and eventual leaf drop
data.Causes: Fungal infection, favored by cool, wet conditions during leaf emergence
data.Treatment: Apply fungicides containing copper or lime sulfur during dormancy

data.Symptoms: Early leaf drop, Gumming on branches
data.Causes: Bacterial infection
data.Treatment: improve air circulation, prune affected branches

data.Symptoms: White, powdery spots on the upper surfaces of leaves, which may coalesce and cover the entire leaf
data.Causes: Fungal infection favored by high humidity and poor air circulation
data.Treatment: Improve air circulation around the plant by pruning neighboring vegetation. Remove affected leaves and dispose of them properly

data.Symptoms: Leaves may become distorted, and overall plant growth may be stunted
data.Causes: occurs due to overwatering or poor soil drainage
data.Treatment: Apply fungicidal sprays containing sulfur, neem oil, or potassium bicarbonate

data.Symptoms: Small, water-soaked lesions on leaves that later turn brown and necrotic. Lesions may coalesce, leading to defoliation and reduced fruit yield
data.Causes: Bacterial infection, spread through splashing water and contaminated tools
data.Treatment: Remove and destroy infected plant material, practice crop rotation, apply copper-based bactericides, and avoid overhead irrigation

data.Symptoms: White powdery patches on leaves, stems, and pods
data.Causes: Fungal infection, favored by warm days, cool nights, and high humidity
data.Treatment: Apply fungicides containing sulfur or potassium bicarbonate

data.Symptoms: Leaves may become distorted or yellowed, leading to reduced photosynthesis and yield
data.Causes: The fungi Uromyces pisi and Uromyces fabae
data.Treatment: Remove affected plant parts,improve air circulation, and avoid overhead watering

data.Symptoms: Infested carrots may have tunnels bored into the root, causing internal damage and rot
data.Causes: Larvae of the carrot rust fly, which feed on carrot roots
data.Treatment: Use row covers to prevent adult flies from laying eggs on carrot plants

data.Symptoms: Affected roots may become discolored, corky, or deformed
data.Causes: In warm and humid conditions, especially during the growing season
data.Treatment: Practice crop rotation and avoid planting carrots in the same area for consecutive years. Harvest carrots promptly to minimize exposure to egg-laying adults

data.Symptoms: Wilting, yellowing, and stunted growth
data.Causes: Fungal infection, typically exacerbated by overwatering
data.Treatment:
Improve soil drainage by amending with organic matter.
Avoid overwatering and waterlogged conditions

data.Symptoms: Roots may appear dark, mushy, and have a foul odor
data.Causes: A variety of soil-borne fungi and oomycetes
data.Treatment: Remove and destroy infected plants, and apply fungicides containing biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp

data.Symptoms: Wilting, yellowing, and stunting of plants
data.Causes: Fungal infection, which blocks water uptake in the plant's vascular system, Bacterial infection leads to leaf spots
data.Treatment:
Plant resistant basil varieties.
Practice crop rotation and soil solarization to reduce pathogen populations

data.Symptoms:
Leaves may curl downward and exhibit chlorosis.
Vascular discoloration may be visible when stems are cut
data.Causes:
Overwatering leads to mold growth on the soil surface.
If left unchecked, it can harm the plant
data.Treatment: Remove affected plants promptly to prevent spread and avoid overhead watering

data.Symptoms: Yellowing of leaves, accompanied by the development of downy white or purplish growth on the undersides of leaves
data.Causes: Fungal infection, favored by cool
data.Treatment: Remove infected plant material, improve air circulation

data.Symptoms: Leaves may become distorted, and plant growth can be stunted
data.Causes: humid conditions, causing yellowing leaves
data.Treatment: avoid overhead irrigation, and apply fungicides containing copper or mancozeb
